edge.line_body: *The flowers are staring at you intently.*
*The flowers are staring at you intently.*
*Stare back*
*Ask what's wrong*
*Ask how their day has been*
*Ask how they feel about the political situation at the moment*
*Ask for their best omelette recipe*
*Ask them to think of a number between 1 and 100*
*You engage in the fiercest staring contest you've ever participate in, but lose when you realise that flowers do not need to blink.*
*The flowers give you detailed instructions on how to make an omelette. *
*Before you can say anything, the flowers interrupt you loudly*.
*They explain how Darf has treated them like dirt (by literally burying them in dirt) and forced them to put up with crappy work conditions.*
*"That's probably just fertiliser", you think to yourself but decide not to vocalise as they continue their diatribe.*
*It's a really long diatribe. You seriously can't even believe how long a speech this is.*
*You wish there was a way that you could just read some narration describing how long the speech is, instead of hearing the actual thing.*
*Sadly such a thing is impossible, but just as you begin to give up hope on exiting the conversation, they finish.*
*You decide to make like a flower and run away as far as possible before they can assault your eardrums again.*
*The flowers are staring at you intently.*
*Greet them through a series of formal buzzes*
*Skip the pleasantries and start negotiating (by buzzing)*
*Buzz about something completely unrelated to anything*
*The flowers sense your hesitation and start ranting about how cold it is in the winter. Sensing that this will go nowhere, you make an excuse and leave.*
*The flowers feel insulted that you would start talking business without even a hello.*
*They tear into you for being so incredibly inpolite but thankfully get distracted when they hear Darf sneeze and start complaining to each other, letting you escape unnoticed.*
*You begin lecturing the flowers about the morality of not resetting the timer on the microwave.*
*Despite being unfamiliar with such technology, the flowers are enraptured by the sheer mundanity and triviality of your complaining, and nod along to everything you say.*
*Halfway through your impassioned speech, you realise that you really need to swing the conversation towards the flowers' protests.*
*Buzz that you really hate it when people don't respect your time(r settings) to change topics*
*Buzz that you once put tinfoil in the microwave and it went really poorly, and speaking of which, the flowers would probably like something to keep them warm*
*Awkwardly buzz about the poor weather we've been having lately*
*Midway through a sentence, start buzzing about how you think you can negotiate a deal between the flowers and Darf*
*The flowers sense your change of topic and immediately interrupt you to tell you about how the sun keeps getting in their eyes from where they're planted.*
*They wrestle the conversation out of your control and slam it into the very same soil they keep complaining about.*
*The flowers politely and calmly (but slightly patronisingly) explain to you that they do not have the nerves to experience temperature directly.*
*You agree that what you said was presumptive and apologise before resuming your lecture about kitchen appliances.*
*The flowers don't even say anything but look at you with a disappointed and annoyed look on their petals. You leave in shame.*
*The flowers all murmur in agreement, still transfixed by your original lecture.*
*Upon switching to a topic that they're more familiar with, they begin to remember the fact that they were protesting.*
*As you observe the flowers begin to get worked up again, you decide to take the initiative and start explaining how you've already talked things over with Darf.*
*They seem angry at first but as you describe in unnecessary detail the measures that you plan to tell Darf later to take, the mood begins to shift.*
*By the end of your speech you notice some of the flowers are tearing up. A few seconds later you realise that flowers don't have tear ducts, and it's actually just rain.*
*Even so, the flowers tell you once you're done that if those promises are lived up to, they can certainly agree to start blooming.*
*Having said that, they also explain that it is currently winter and blooming now is not really feasible.*
*You see their point and are beginning to doubt if Darf understands gardening very well. But you can probably return to him regardless.*
*The flowers are staring at you intently.*
*You announce to the flowers that you agree that they're been treated very harshly and you want to join their protests.*
*The flowers respond to this with rapturous applause, except that the sound of leaves hitting each other is pretty quiet so it just seems like an awkward silence.*
*Regardless, they happily accept you as one of them.*
*Just when you think you'll be able to discuss plans for the protests going forward, they instead start gossiping about some shrubs.*
*You keep searching for ways to join their conversation but realise you fundamentally don't care about flower politics.*
*Was joining their protest for basically no reason whatsoever a mistake?*
*You'll never see eye to eye with Darf again, and these flowers clearly don't make for good company. Not to mention the fact that they can't move.*
*The consequences of this choice will surely have a tremendous effect many generations from now, or at least until you decide to close this game.*
*The flowers are staring at you fondly.*
